question: Given that Earth’s atmosphere is 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen by volume, which two gases make up most of the atmosphere?

content.source_1: Dry air near Earth’s surface is about 78% nitrogen (N2) by volume.
content.source_2: Dry air near Earth’s surface is about 21% oxygen (O2) by volume.
content.source_3: Argon is about 0.93% and carbon dioxide about 0.04% of dry air by volume; all other gases occur only in trace amounts.
content.source_4: The exosphere—the outermost layer of Earth’s atmosphere—is composed primarily of very light gases; hydrogen and helium are the most abundant species there.
content.source_5: The exosphere begins around 500–600 km and extends to roughly 10,000 km altitude, making it the thickest and most spatially extensive atmospheric layer.
